div.p: Pine Lake Prep offers school based therapists for our K-12 students. The selected therapists and agencies are located within the Mooresville-Lake Norman area and have been authorized to deliver services on the PLP campus while school is open. The goal of this School Based Therapy Initiative is to reduce the barriers to accessing professional mental health counseling and support. Families whose students are referred may engage the service provider and receive services at school
Sessions will be 45-50 minutes long and will take place during a convenient time of day for your child (study hall, lunch, end of one class/start of the next class).
Professional fees charged by the therapists will be handled directly with families, as the therapists are not employees of the school.
* Note: Confidentiality will be upheld. The therapist will not share with the school counselors or staff any
information unless the parent requests it to be shared and the proper documentation is signed.
For more information, please contact your designated School Counselor.

Middle School: Natalie Goodwin
Lower School: Aislinn Mayes

If your family is experiencing job loss, please look into this option as a way to help your family during this unprecedented time. The full list of how to qualify can be found online here.

li.a: March 13: Campus Closed Beginning March 16. eLearning Begins March 18

div.p: Good evening, PLP:
In an effort to continually keep our families informed with the latest information, I wanted to follow up regarding a few decisions out of Raleigh.

p.strong: Campus will be closed through May 15th

div.p: This afternoon, Governor Cooper signed an executive order that will close public K-12 schools across North Carolina for in-person instruction until May 15th. While all signs were pointing to an extended timeline, this edict provides more clarity around an earliest potential return date for us.

With that being said, I am encouraged that eLearning is off to a great start and it will only get better. I am happy to say that today, our attendance at the middle and upper school was 97.8% – students are logged on and engaged.

State Superintendent Johnson commented on the importance of continued learning, stating, “we cannot treat this as a long break.” Please understand we fully intend to leverage eLearning to maximize the time left in the year as much as possible.

p.strong: End of Grade/End of Course Tests

div.p: This morning, the North Carolina State Board of Education voted unanimously to seek a one-year waiver from the U.S. Department of Education for federal student testing and accountability requirements for the 2019-20 school year because of school closures associated with the COVID-19 pandemic. As our communication yesterday alluded to, any request from states to bypass testing requirements will be honored based on the President's declaration this past weekend. We anticipate this will become official in the next 48 hours.

Please note that, while we are not mandated to administer state testing, we will continue to teach our planned curriculum. Teachers will still be testing on the material, and student engagement remains a necessity and expectation. With that being said, this should reduce some of the anxiety while also giving us more flexibility and time to try new, innovative and creative things in our virtual classrooms over the next few months.

The North Carolina tests that would be waived include end-of-grade tests in reading and math in grades 3 through 8, science tests in grades 5 and 8 and end-of-course tests in Math 1 and 3, Biology and English 2. The waiver would also include the state’s A-F school performance grades as well as a number of elements included in the state’s school report cards.

Advanced Placement (AP) testing will still take place in the spring however, it will undoubtedly look different. AP is developing secure 45-minute online free-response exams for each course. The exam content will focus on what most schools were able to complete by early March and students will be able to take exams on their school issued computers. Colleges support this solution and are committed to ensuring that AP students receive the credit they have worked to earn. Colleges have historically accepted a shortened AP Exam for college credit when groups of students have experienced emergencies.
Please encourage your son or daughter to talk with their AP teacher for more information.

ACT Testing: ACT has rescheduled its April 4 national test date to June 13 across the U.S. in response to concerns about the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19). All students registered for the April 4 test date will receive an email from ACT in the next few days informing them of the postponement and instructions for free rescheduling to June 13 or a future national test date. Learn more.

SAT Testing: In response to the rapidly evolving situation around the coronavirus (COVID-19), College Board is canceling the May 2, 2020 SAT and SAT Subject Test administration. Makeup exams for the March 14 administration (scheduled for March 28) are also canceled.

While we all miss being on campus with our students, we are committed to celebrating important milestones with the Class of 2020. Graduation is currently still scheduled as planned, however, we will communicate a new date as soon as possible, if health concerns remain, or continued group limitations are still in place.
Thank you for your support,
Andrew Moceri

Executive Director
Pine Lake Preparatory

We have worked through a few of the minor tweaks this afternoon and are looking to tomorrow’s “B day” with optimism. We recognize that the system started to slow around 10:00 am (3rd block). I look forward to seeing the kids online tomorrow.

h2.a: March 13: Campus Closed Beginning March 16. eLearning Begins March 18

div.p: Pine Lake families,

Today we have made the decision to cancel school on Monday, March 16th and Tuesday, March 17th. Effective on Wednesday, March 18th, Pine Lake Preparatory will operate in an eLearning setting. With the exception of eLearning, all school activities, including after school care will be suspended until further notice.

The COVID-19 virus is an unprecedented situation. We have been preparing for a situation that has been changing daily, and more recently, hourly. With that being said, we are prepared to maintain the momentum of learning in an online setting.

Closing PLP is the responsible choice that will minimize the risk of exposure for our students, staff, families and the general public. Decisions like this are not only for the protection of the PLP community, but also the surrounding community – we have a responsibility to do our part.

Each of the three school buildings will be open on Monday, March 16th and Tuesday, March 17th with limited staff available. These days will not be used for instruction, but instead will give families more time to come into school buildings and get any items they may need for the extra time off, such as medication from the school nurse or administrative assistants.

School buildings will then be closed for students effective Wednesday, March 18th . During that time, administration will support eLearning, continue to work with health officials to monitor the situation, and ensure campus is continually and thoroughly disinfected. At this point, we expect to be out at a minimum through March 27th.

This is the first of three emails you will receive this weekend. The second will arrive at 10:00 am tomorrow with considerations for the next few weeks and the third will be sent Sunday at 10:00 am regarding eLearning procedures.
Please recognize that eLearning has been our priority. We will work through individual field trip communications, refund notices, and other outstanding items in the coming weeks.
I appreciate your flexibility and support over the next few weeks,
Andrew Moceri
Executive Director
Pine Lake Preparatory
Dear Pine Lake families,

The North Carolina High School Athletics Association has decided to suspend interscholastic athletics due to the threat from COVID-19, effective Friday, March 13. Coaches will be prepared to notify their Middle and Upper School teams and families this afternoon. This suspension will include all practices, games and team activities.
We will work with the NCSAA to re-evaluate the situation in two weeks.
Thank you,
Andrew Moceri
Executive Director

p.b: As many of you know, North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper declared a state of emergency to help mitigate the spread of COVID-19. I wanted to provide an update related to the impact of this on school and school related operations, as well as give a general update on our current position.

First, it is important to note that state officials have specifically recommended that schools should not be closed at this time. This recommendation reflects the current guidance that children are at a low risk of serious illness. The Iredell Health Department also currently has the risk level to the general public listed at low.

At this time, Pine Lake Preparatory is canceling or postponing all school sponsored field trips out of the county, effective today. In addition, we will continue to evaluate future school events that attract large crowds. You will receive specific updates regarding these events in the coming days - I ask for your patience as we work through each event/trip. While I recognize some will agree with the decision and others may disagree, the decision has been made out of an abundance of caution for our students, staff and family. While we can take steps to mitigate risk at school, local and domestic trips involving charter buses, hotels and tourist attractions present variables and risks we cannot control.

As of today, there are no changes to athletic and school events, however, we urge everyone to follow guidance from North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services when deciding whether to attend an event. A major consideration; people aged 65 and older, anyone with underlying medical conditions, and those who are ill should avoid events that attract crowds.

To help mitigate rumors or concerns, I will tell you that specific to Pine Lake Preparatory, we have not seen an increase in illness or absences. We are not aware of any students who have been tested for the COVID-19 virus or who have been at risk for infection. We are in conversation with the Iredell Health Department and if a community (or more specifically, a school) has cases of COVID-19, local health officials would follow up directly with us on next steps. Those steps would certainly include transparent communication to our families. Furthermore, we are in collaboration with local schools and districts to ensure the transparent flow of information and/or potential concerns.
As we communicated previously, we are finalizing plans in the event that circumstances reach a point that the county, state or CDC recommends closing school temporarily.
Please continue to remind your students to practice everyday preventive actions which can help prevent the spread of respiratory illness, including:
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.
Stay home when you are sick.
Cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces using a regular household cleaning spray or wipe – door knobs, lights switches, faucets, etc.
Wash your hands with warm often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after going to the bathroom; before eating; and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.

I thank you in advance for the grace and patience that will no doubt be required in the coming days. We are all working together to support a safe and healthy learning environment while at the same time approaching the situation with reason.

h5.a: Talking with Children About Coronavirus: Tips from the Centers for Disease Control

div.p: As public conversations around coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) increase, children may worry about themselves, their family, and friends getting ill with COVID-19. Parents, family members, school staff, and other trusted adults can play an important role in helping children make sense of what they hear in a way that is honest, accurate, and minimizes anxiety or fear. CDC has created guidance to help adults have conversations with children about COVID-19 and ways they can avoid getting and spreading the disease.
General principles for talking to children

ul.li: Remember that children will react to both what you say and how you say it. They will pick up cues from the conversations you have with them and with others.

p.strong: Make yourself available to listen and to talk.

ul.li: Make time to talk. Be sure children know they can come to you when they have questions.

div.p: Avoid language that might blame others and lead to stigma.

ul.li: Remember that viruses can make anyone sick, regardless of a person’s race or ethnicity. Avoid making assumptions about who might have COVID-19.

p.strong: Pay attention to what children see or hear on television, radio, or online.

ul.li: Consider reducing the amount of screen time focused on COVID-19. Too much information on one topic can lead to anxiety.

p.strong: Provide information that is honest and accurate.

ul.li: Give children information that is truthful and appropriate for the age and developmental level of the child.
Talk to children about how some stories on COVID-19 on the Internet and social media may be based on rumors and inaccurate information.

p.strong: Teach children everyday actions to reduce the spread of germs.

ul.li: Remind children to stay away from people who are coughing or sneezing or sick.
Remind them to cough or sneeze into a tissue or their elbow, then throw the tissue into the trash.

Discuss any new actions that may be taken at school to help protect children and school staff.
(e.g., increased handwashing, cancellation of events or activities)

Get children into a handwashing habit.
Teach them to wash their hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing their nose, coughing, or sneezing; going to the bathroom; and before eating or preparing food.
If soap and water are not available, teach them to use hand sanitizer. Hand sanitizer should contain at least 60% alcohol. Supervise young children when they use hand sanitizer to prevent swallowing alcohol, especially in schools and childcare facilities.
